channel.title: Wombat Forest - Fungi
channel.description: The purpose of this group it to provide a photographic record of fungi species found within the Wombat Forest. Images should be sharp, close, and include features necessary for identification such as cap detail, gills/pores/spines and stem detail where possible. Not all fungi can be readily identified to species level without the aid of detailed microscopic examination and it is also not necessarily easy to identify the genus, however we wish to record all species found in the forest, both named and unnamed. While it is not intended that this be a "post your image for identification" site, efforts will be made to correct or offer names where possible. There is some overlap with the northern parts of the forest and the Drummond & nearby forest group and a separate group has been established for Macedon Ranges - Fungi.

item.title: Clitocybe spp.
item.dc:creator: zeke1944
item.description: Clitocybe brunneoceracea. Seen on wood near Lerderderg River.

item.title: Gymnopilus eucalyptorum
item.dc:creator: zeke1944
item.description: Small saprophyte found on large logs. Cap to 20mm. Stem has a white bloom.

item.title: Gymnopilus spp.
item.dc:creator: zeke1944
item.description: Gymnopilus austropicreus. (B.J.Rees) Small saprophyte often on large logs. Cap to 30mm. Gates p83.

item.title: Clitopilus spp.
item.dc:creator: zeke1944
item.description: Small fan shaped species that is found on rocks growing with mosses. Cap to 5mm. Gates p42. Clitopilus kamaka . J.A. Cooper. Spore print Brownish pink.

item.title: Cortinarius spp.
item.dc:creator: zeke1944
item.description: Yellow sp with some purple hues. Unknown to me.

item.title: Podoserpula pusio
item.dc:creator: zeke1944
item.description: On wood an old stump close to, the ground. Close to Lerderderg river.

item.title: Simocybe phlebophora
item.dc:creator: zeke1944
item.description: Small Mycena like species usually on fallen wood or stumps. The Khaki colored cap has a layer of gell under the outer skin causing a wrinkled appearance. Cal to 40mm.

item.title: Dacrymyces spp.
item.dc:creator: zeke1944
item.description: Small jelly balls to about 5mm diam. A reasonable fit for Dacrymyces aff stillatus. Found on a wet log with Calocera sp.

item.title: Cortinarius austrocyanites
item.dc:creator: zeke1944
item.description: Gates P49. Dark purplish cap with brown fibrils. The gills are sky blue colored untill becoming redbrown with ripening spore. Seen in the upper reaches of the Campaspe River.

item.title: Clitocybula sp. nov. sensu Gates & Ratkowsky(1) 2016
item.dc:creator: 249pbr
item.description: 4 Images. This is Clitocybula sp. "Streaky Yellow", a little scruffy on top due to the heavy rain.
item.category: id~Clitocybula sp. nov. sensu Gates & Ratkowsky(1) 2016

item.title: Cortinarius pseudorotundisporus
item.dc:creator: 249pbr
item.description: Several images

item.title: Agaricus sp. nov. sensu Gates & Ratkowsky(1) 2016
item.dc:creator: zeke1944
item.category: id~Agaricus sp. nov. sensu Gates & Ratkowsky(1) 2016

item.title: Psilocybe brunneoalbescens
item.dc:creator: zeke1944
item.description: On partially buried well rotted wood on the bank of the Lerderderg river.

item.title: Mesophellia spp.
item.dc:creator: 249pbr
item.description: Three images. A truffle-like species which is unusual in that the spores form in a space around an infertile core. The core is believed to be high in nutrients which is the reward for the mammal that finds, eats and disperses the species. In other truffle-like species virtually all the inside of the fungus contains fertile spore producing material.

item.title: Gymnopus sp. nov. sensu Gates & Ratkowsky(1) 2016
item.dc:creator: zeke1944
item.description: Gymnopus Pink Furry
item.category: id~Gymnopus sp. nov. sensu Gates & Ratkowsky(1) 2016

item.title: Stereum ostrea
item.dc:creator: 249pbr
item.description: Other images show underside. This species has had a name change and is now Stereum versicolor.

item.title: Xylaria hypoxylon
item.dc:creator: 249pbr
item.description: Several images, a taller species, all white when young and fresh

item.title: Xylaria apiculata
item.dc:creator: 249pbr
item.description: Several images of the short white-tipped species.

item.title: Nidula niveotomentosa
item.dc:creator: 249pbr
item.description: Several images including what I think are unopened cups

item.title: Lactarius piperatus
item.dc:creator: 249pbr
item.description: Two images. This is Lactarius piperatus, please add to the database

item.title: Grifola colensoi
item.dc:creator: 249pbr
item.description: This is Grifola colensoi, could the database be updated please. Two images. Most times I have found this species it has been mostly eaten by the Black Wallabies.

item.title: Grifola spp.
item.dc:creator: 249pbr
item.description: This is a Grifola species that looks a little different from the species generally photographed and labelled as Grifola colensoi. Two images.

item.title: Roridomyces austrororidus
item.dc:creator: 249pbr
item.description: This is Roridomyces austrororidus, formerly known as Mycena austrororida. Could it be added to the database please.

item.title: Neolentiporus maculatissimus
item.dc:creator: 249pbr
item.description: Also Neolentiporus maculatissimus, several images

item.title: Neolentiporus maculatissimus
item.dc:creator: 249pbr
item.description: Several images of Neolentiporus maculatissimus, a FungiMap species. Could it be added to the database please.

item.title: Mycena fumosa
item.dc:creator: 249pbr
item.description: Two images, this species lacks the orange collar at the base of the stem making it easy to separate from the similar M. carmeliana

item.title: Mycena cystidiosa
item.dc:creator: 249pbr
item.description: A few of the pseudostipes common with this species can be seen in the background of both images

item.title: Pseudomerulius curtisii
item.dc:creator: 249pbr
item.description: 3 images - a plain upper surface conceals the golden maze-like gills

item.title: Pholiota malicola
item.dc:creator: 249pbr
item.description: Several images

item.title: Byssomerulius corium
item.dc:creator: 249pbr
item.description: Several images

item.title: Mycena interrupta
item.dc:creator: 249pbr
item.description: Several images

item.title: Discinella terrestris
item.dc:creator: 249pbr
item.description: This species was known as Discinella terrestris, however it has been changed on ALA to Phaeohelotium baileyanum. Could the database please be updated.

item.title: Schizophyllum commune
item.dc:creator: 249pbr
item.description: Second images shows the distinctive underside of this species, it is also known as 'Split Gills'. It is recommended that you avoid breathing the spores of this species.

item.title: Pyronema omphalodes
item.dc:creator: 249pbr
item.description: On freshly burnt ground

item.title: Ceriporiopsis merulinus
item.dc:creator: 249pbr
item.description: Second image shows fine detail of the pores

item.title: Cruentomycena viscidocruenta
item.dc:creator: 249pbr
item.description: The frequently slimy stem and red edged white gills are distinctive features

item.title: Hygrocybe pseudograminicolor
item.dc:creator: 249pbr
item.description: Several images. This species was believed to be associated with Myrtle Beech, Nothofagus cunninghamii, but now I have located it at two locations in the Wombat Forest plus there is a record to the north of Macedon. Like its near namesake, it could be a Gliophorus soon.

item.title: Hygrocybe graminicolor
item.dc:creator: 249pbr
item.description: A younger specimen still with the green cap.

item.title: Hygrocybe graminicolor
item.dc:creator: 249pbr
item.description: Several images. This species starts off with a green cap that ages to brown. The current status of this name is not clear, Index Fungorum lists it as Gliophorus graminicolor whereas ALA still retains the older title, Hygrocybe graminicolor.

item.title: Ramaria lorithamnus
item.dc:creator: 249pbr
item.description: Several images which were 'photo-bombed' by a group of Mycena subvulgaris

item.title: Mycena subvulgaris
item.dc:creator: 249pbr
item.description: Several images including the pure white decurrent gills

item.title: Psathyrella pennata
item.dc:creator: 249pbr
item.description: 3 images, second shows close up of fresh gills with the black spores starting to discolour the gills, third image has a small group with older discoloured gills

item.title: Geastrum triplex
item.dc:creator: 249pbr
item.description: Second image shows an unopened tear-drop shaped star

item.title: Geoglossum spp.
item.dc:creator: 249pbr
item.description: Three images, they appear black in the field but the camera flash shows their true colour is brown

item.title: Hypocrea lixii
item.dc:creator: 249pbr
item.description: The greenish black colour of these small cushions identifies them as Hypocrea lixii. Could this species be included in the database please. Second image shows more of the group.

item.title: Resupinatus subapplicatus
item.dc:creator: 249pbr
item.description: Second image shows the gills in greater detail

item.title: Phlebia subceracea
item.dc:creator: 249pbr
item.description: This is Phlebia subceracea, previously known as Mycoacia subceracea, it is not listed in the database under either name so needs to be added please. It is not always this orange looking, frequently having a more yellow appearance.

item.title: Lasiosphaeria ovina
item.dc:creator: 249pbr
item.description: These tiny white fluffy balls with a black central eye are not often seen

item.title: Crepidotus nephrodes
item.dc:creator: 249pbr
item.description: Two images, second has underside. Crepidotus species have brown spores

item.title: Hohenbuehelia clelandii
item.dc:creator: 249pbr
item.description: Two images

item.title: Callistosporium spp.
item.dc:creator: 249pbr
item.description: 3 images, this looks very similar to the last species (Tubaria rufofulva), but lacks the annulus and has white spores, The gill edge is also coloured. This is an as yet unnamed species of Callistosporium, recorded as Callistosporium 'maroon with yellow rhizomorphs' in Gates & Ratkowsky - A Field Guide to Tasmanian Fungi. Could Callistosporium spp be added to the database please.

item.title: Tubaria rufofulva
item.dc:creator: 249pbr
item.description: 3 Images, this is Tubaria rufofulva. Could the database be updated please. This species has an annulus (ring on stem) and brown spores which you can see in the first image.

item.title: Psilocybe subaeruginosa
item.dc:creator: 249pbr
item.description: 3 images, the second images shows a little of the blue staining that confirms the identity of this species

item.title: Artomyces colensoi
item.dc:creator: 249pbr
item.description: Two images, the smaller coral species occurring on wood

item.title: Artomyces piperatus
item.dc:creator: 249pbr
item.description: One of two coral species that occurs on wood, this is the larger species

item.title: Pseudohydnum gelatinosum
item.dc:creator: 249pbr
item.description: Two images

item.title: Torrendiella eucalypti
item.dc:creator: 249pbr
item.description: This species now has a new name - Hymenotorrendiella eucalypti, could this be updated please, The tiny cups are around 1-1.75mm in diameter and they only occur on the leaves of the Blackwood, Acacia melanoxylon in wet forest. Like much of Australia's fungi, this species was named from collections sent overseas, in this instance M. J. Berkeley described it's habit as "on leaves of Eucalyptus", hence the naming error.

item.title: Psathyrella echinata
item.dc:creator: 249pbr
item.description: This image shows the full development of the species with tiny furry buttons on the far left through to collapsing and spent mushroom on the far right. Second images shows closer detail of the main group.

item.title: Fistulinella mollis
item.dc:creator: 249pbr
item.description: See cap in second image. A soft marshmallow-like bolete.

item.title: Orbilia spp.
item.dc:creator: 249pbr
item.description: These tiny translucent orange discs look very much like Orbilia cf xanthostigma as reported in the the Gates & Ratkowsky publication A Field Guide to Tasmanian Fungi. Best left as Orbilia sp. for now.

item.title: Cystolepiota spp.
item.dc:creator: 249pbr
item.description: An as yet unnamed species but reported in the Gates & Ratkowsky publication A Field Guide to Tasmanian Fungi as Cystolepiota sp. 'small white'. The daggy bits hanging off the edge of the cap and the white gills are indicative of the species. Two images.

item.title: Mycena epipterygia
item.dc:creator: 249pbr
item.description: It seems that there is a group of yellow-stemmed Mycena species that are all covered under the name Mycena epipterygia Group until further research is completed.

item.title: Pleurotopsis longinqua
item.dc:creator: 249pbr
item.description: Two images

item.title: Pleurotopsis longinqua
item.dc:creator: 249pbr
item.description: Several images - this species is now known as Scytinotus longinquus, could the name be updated please

item.title: Deconica horizontalis
item.dc:creator: 249pbr
item.description: Three images, this is Deconica horizontalis, previously recorded as Melanotus hepatochrous in one field guide and as Psilocybe hepatochrous in another guide. It appears on ALA, could the database be updated please. It is similar to the previous species but has purple/brown spores.

item.title: Panellus stipticus
item.dc:creator: 249pbr
item.description: Two images. This is a white spored species.

item.title: Panellus ligulatus
item.dc:creator: 249pbr
item.description: Two images

item.title: Coprinopsis nivea
item.dc:creator: 249pbr
item.description: This species grown on animal dung

item.title: Simocybe phlebophora
item.dc:creator: 249pbr
item.description: Several images

item.title: Mycena mulawaestris
item.dc:creator: 249pbr
item.description: Several images

item.title: Mycena mulawaestris
item.dc:creator: 249pbr
item.description: Three images showing underside and gloop

item.title: Mycena roseoflava
item.dc:creator: 249pbr
item.description: Two images. This is Mycena roseoflava, could the database be update to include this species. The small pink caps can cover large areas on logs in wet forest. You might see a yellowish base to the stipes (stems) of some which is a clue to identification.

item.title: Mycena clarkeana
item.dc:creator: 249pbr
item.description: See gills on second image

item.title: Cortinarius memoria-annae
item.dc:creator: 249pbr
item.description: Several images.The stipe quickly bruises to yellow readily identifying this species

item.title: Ramaria flaccida
item.dc:creator: 249pbr
item.description: Several images. This species is now known as Phaeoclavulina flaccida, could this be updated please.

item.title: Stereum illudens
item.dc:creator: 249pbr
item.description: Several images including the hairy brown upper surface.

item.title: Boletellus obscurecoccineus
item.dc:creator: 249pbr
item.description: Second image shows upper cap

item.title: Gloeophyllum spp.
item.dc:creator: 249pbr
item.description: See second image for upper surface. Found on old Pinus radiata wood. This is Gloeophyllum sepiarium could the database be updated please.

item.title: Hypholoma fasciculare var. armeniacum
item.dc:creator: 249pbr
item.description: This is Hypholoma fasciculare var armeniacum, noted for its smaller size and orange cap and gills making it quite distinct from the more common Hypholoma fasciculare var fasciculare in the images below. Could this be added to the database please.

item.title: Hypholoma australe, Hypholoma fasciculare
item.dc:creator: 249pbr
item.description: Second image shows gills of both species, the dark discolouration on the gills is the spores.

item.title: Bisporella sulfurina
item.dc:creator: 249pbr
item.description: This discs are tiny

item.title: Flammulina velutipes
item.dc:creator: 249pbr
item.description: Several images showing gills and velvet stipe

item.title: Cortinarius persplendidus
item.dc:creator: 249pbr
item.description: You must look at the photos of the gills of this species.The first view is quite a shock to most people.Three images.

item.title: Gymnopilus eucalyptorum
item.dc:creator: 249pbr
item.description: Three images.

item.title: Cantharellus spp.
item.dc:creator: 249pbr
item.description: This much rarer species has also been described to me as Cantharellus concinnus but its form is so different that I struggle to think of it as being the same. Like the previous posting, the location is a general guide only. Two images.

item.title: Cantharellus concinnus
item.dc:creator: 249pbr
item.description: This species is listed as Cantharellus concinnus, could the database be updated please. The location as used here is a general guide only due to this being a prized edible species that I would rather see doing its work in the forest than sitting on a gourmand's dinner plate. Four images.

item.title: Neobarya agaricicola
item.dc:creator: 249pbr
item.description: This is Neobarya agaricicola that feeds on the older fruit bodies of other fungi such as Galerina species. It produces tiny golden pear-shaped flasks that contain its spores. Could it be added to the database please.

item.title: Ascocoryne sarcoides
item.dc:creator: 249pbr
item.description: The smaller white capped clubs are the conidial (asexual) phase of this species and the larger purple discs are the spore producers

item.title: Torrendiella clelandii
item.dc:creator: 249pbr
item.description: 3 images - each cup is just a few millimetres across. This species is now known as Hymenotorrendiella clelandii, could this be updated please.

item.title: Ramaria botrytoides
item.dc:creator: 249pbr
item.description: Three images showing different specimens

item.title: Glonium spp.
item.dc:creator: 249pbr
item.description: Several images

item.title: Ramariopsis crocea
item.dc:creator: 249pbr
item.description: Two images

item.title: Cortinarius chrysopocos
item.dc:creator: 249pbr
item.description: This is Cortinarius chrysopocos, apparently common in Tasmania but with only one other record in Victoria on ALA, See other images for finer details.Could it be added to the database please

item.title: Cheimonophyllum candidissimum
item.dc:creator: 249pbr
item.description: Two images

item.title: Antrodiella zonata
item.dc:creator: 249pbr
item.description: Three images

item.title: Calostoma fuscum
item.dc:creator: 249pbr
item.description: Three images

item.title: Hydnellum auratile
item.dc:creator: 249pbr
item.description:
This is listed as Hydnellum auratile on the FNCV Fungi Group lists and appears under this name in Fuhrer, A Field Guide to Australian Fungi. Second image shows detail of the tan coloured spines.
The similar looking Phelledon niger is a darker charcoal or black on the cap and has grey spines.

item.title: Gliophorus chromolimoneus
item.dc:creator: 249pbr
item.description: This is Gliophorus chromolimoneus, formerly known as Hygrocybe chromolimonea. The bright yellow cap, stem and gills make this an easy one to identify. Could it be included in the database please.

item.title: Marasmius crinis-equi
item.dc:creator: 249pbr
item.description: This is Marasmius crinis-equi, the small dimple with the dark spot in the centre of the cap and the horse-hair stem (see second image) are clear indentifiers. Please add to database.

item.title: Coltriciella dependens
item.dc:creator: 249pbr
item.description: Not often seen unless you are in the habit of looking at the underside of sticks in the forest.

item.title: Hypoxylon howeanum
item.dc:creator: 249pbr
item.description:
This species is sometimes illustrated in Australia as H. fuscum, The red brick coloured balls are the sexual reproductive stage and the hairy looking star-like clusters nearby are the asexual anamorph stage. See second image for detail on the anamorph.
The tiny pale discs in the first image have not been identified.

item.title: Dermocybe canaria
item.dc:creator: 249pbr
item.description: 3 images - This species is now known as Cortinarius canarius, could the new name be added to the database please. Recent molecular work has returned all the Australian Dermocybe back to Cortinarius

item.title: Ramaria filicicola
item.dc:creator: 249pbr
item.description: 2 images. This species has been previously misidentified as R. gracilis which apparently does not occur in Australia.

item.title: Mucronella pendula
item.dc:creator: 249pbr
item.description: Several images

item.title: Marasmius alveolaris
item.dc:creator: 249pbr
item.description: See other images also

item.title: Ramaria fennica var. fumigata
item.dc:creator: 249pbr
item.description: This is Ramaria fennica var. fumigata, please add to database

item.title: Xeromphalina leonina
item.dc:creator: 249pbr
item.description: See underside in additional images

item.title: Lachnum virgineum
item.dc:creator: 249pbr
item.description: Cups are just 2mm accross

item.title: Phaeoclavulina ochracea
item.dc:creator: 249pbr
item.description: This is Phaeoclavulina ochracea, also called Ramaria ochracea, please add to database. Refer to the downloadable publication on the FNCV website titled "A Little Book of Corals"

item.title: Campanella olivaceonigra
item.dc:creator: 249pbr
item.description: Check out the beautiful gills on second image

item.title: Xylaria sp. nov. sensu Gates & Ratkowsky(1) 2016
item.dc:creator: 249pbr
item.description: This is Xylaria "Spikey", a species not yet formally described but listed under this name in A Field Guide to Tasmanian Fungi by Gates & Ratkowsky
item.category: id~Xylaria sp. nov. sensu Gates & Ratkowsky(1) 2016

item.title: Ramaria anziana
item.dc:creator: 249pbr
item.description: Two images

item.title: Lactarius wirrabara
item.dc:creator: 249pbr
item.description: This is Lactarius wirrabara, could the database be updated please, Second image shows underside.

item.title: Trametes versicolor
item.dc:creator: 249pbr
item.description: You can see my boots in the lower right of the second image, photographing fungi can be hazardous, especially when you are standing on rotten logs.

item.title: Entoloma rodwayi
item.dc:creator: 249pbr
item.description: See other images, the blue staining on the base of the stipe, seen in the last image, is diagnostic for this species.

item.title: Auriscalpium spp.
item.dc:creator: 249pbr
item.description: I am told that this extremely rare species was recently formally named and is now known as Auriscalpium greyorum, after the original finders. It grows on one tree only near Blackwood.

item.title: 123 ids
item.dc:creator: 249pbr
item.description: Species list for collection.
